owl:Ontology.dc:title: EEPSA (Energy Efficiency Prediction Semantic Assistant) Ontology

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: A location not provided by geo-coordinates (i.e. building A, city of Aarhus).
The WGS84 altitude of a SpatialThing (decimal meters above the local reference ellipsoid).
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: altitude

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The WGS84 latitude of a SpatialThing (decimal degrees).
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: latitude

owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:comment: The WGS84 longitude of a SpatialThing (decimal degrees).
owl:AnnotationProperty.rdfs:label: longitude

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation between an Observation and the Spatial Thing (Building, Space) where it has been captured
Relation between a Spatial Thing (Building, Space) and the Observation that has been captured
A relation between a Building Element and the Spatial Structure (Space or Building) in which it is contained
Relation used to assign Building Element to a certain Spatial Structure (Space or Building).
A relation between a physical space and the objects located in such space.
Relation between a Quantity Kind and a data source where values can be retrieved
Relation between a thing and the direction it is oriented
Relation between a Building and its Postal Address
A relation between a Thing (mainly an Outlier) and a Method proposed to solve it
Relation between a building or a building space and the spaces it can be divided into.
Relation between a Thing (Sensor) and a Unit of measurement
Relationship between a space and the Quantity Kind that is affects its indoor conditions
A relation between an object and the physical space in which it is located.
Relationship between a space and the Quantity Kind that is affects its indoor conditions with a higher degree
Relation between a building space and the building or building space it belongs to.

Relation between a Weather Service and the location for which it has been made
*** REVISAR EL NOMBRE Relaciona weather services (reports o forecasts) realizados en o para un lugar (weather station) concreto. No tiene por qué ser weather station, hay veces que los forecasts se realizan para una región
Relation between a Thing (weather station) and the Weather Service it provices (weather report, weather forecast,...)

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Model of a Thing (normally a Physical Object)
Manufacturer of a Thing (normally a Physical Object)
Determines the Date (e.g. yyyy-mm-dd) of a temporal thing
Determines the Time (e.g. hh:mm:ss) of a temporal thing
Determines the timestamp of a temporal thing

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:isDefinedBy: The address of the postal address (typically stree name, number, floor,...)

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: The name of the country of the postal address
The postal code of the town of the postal address
The name of the region of the postal address

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:isDefinedBy: The name of the town of the postal address

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Indication whether this building storey is fully above ground (TRUE), or below ground (FALSE). The indication of partially above and below ground (UNKNOWN) - as in sloped terrain is not covered to simplify it.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Property Set (pset) common to Storeys (Pset_BuildingStoreyCommon), but used for Spaces, since in our ontology the ifcStorey is not covered.

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Indication whether the element is designed for use in the exterior (TRUE) or not (FALSE). If (TRUE) it is an external element and faces the outside of the building.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Property Sets (pset) common to doors (Pset_DoorCommon), walls (Pset_WallCommon) and windows (Pset_WindowCommon)

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Status of the element, predominately used in renovation or retrofitting projects. The status can be assigned to as "New" - element designed as new addition, "Existing" - element exists and remains, "Demolish" - element existed but is to be demolished, "Temporary" - element will exists only temporary (like a temporary support structure), "Other" - value is not listed, "NotKnown" - value is unknown, "Unset" - value has not been specified.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Property Sets (pset) common to doors (Pset_DoorCommon), walls (Pset_WallCommon) and windows (Pset_WindowCommon)

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment:
Thermal transmittance coefficient (U-Value) of an element.
Lower numbers are better when comparing U-Values. The U-Value judges a material's insulation ability
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:isDefinedBy: Property Sets (pset) common to doors (Pset_DoorCommon), walls (Pset_WallCommon) and windows (Pset_WindowCommon)

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:seeAlso: Indication whether a device is sheltered (TRUE) or not (FALSE)

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: A datatype property that encodes values from a datatype for an Entity. There are several ways to encode values in DOLCE (Ultralite): 1) Directly assert an xsd:_ value to an Entity by using hasDataValue 2) Assert a Region for an Entity by using hasRegion, and then assert an xsd:_ value to that Region, by using hasRegionDataValue 3) Assert a Quality for an Entity by using hasQuality, then assert a Region for that Quality, and assert an xsd:_ value to that Region, by using hasRegionDataValue 4) When the value is required, but not directly observed, assert a Parameter for an xsd:_ value by using hasParameterDataValue, and then associate the Parameter to an Entity by using isConstraintFor 5) When the value is required, but not directly observed, you can also assert a Parameter for a Region by using parametrizes, and then assert an xsd:_ value to that Region, by using hasRegionDataValue The five approaches obey different requirements. For example, a simple value can be easily asserted by using pattern (1), but if one needs to assert an interval between two values, a Region should be introduced to materialize that interval, as pattern (2) suggests. Furthermore, if one needs to distinguish the individual Quality of a value, e.g. the particular nature of the density of a substance, pattern (3) can be used. Patterns (4) and (5) should be used instead when a constraint or a selection is modeled, independently from the actual observation of values in the real world.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: has data value

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: This is a placeholder for events that are considered in their evolution, or anyway not strictly dependent on agents, tasks, and plans. See Event class for some thoughts on classifying events. See also 'Transition'.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Actuator used to put the blinds up or down

Definition according to ISO 6707-1: Construction work that has the provision of shelter for its occupants or contents as one of its main purpose and is normally designed to stand permanently in one place.
The building element comprises all elements that are primarily part of the construction of a building, i.e., its structural and space separating system.
A space represents an area or volume bounded actually or theoretically. Spaces are areas or volumes that provide for certain functions within a building.

A method that consists in placing the sensing device in an adequate location. Following guides can be followed:
https://www.rmets.org/sites/default/files/pdf/guidelines/aws-guide.pdf
http://weatherfaqs.org.uk/node/124
http://www.conservationphysics.org/datalog/datlog6.php
http://www.weatherstations.co.uk/gooddata.htm

A method that consists in covering the sensing device adequately to avoid erroneous observations. For example, Stevenson Screen to shield the sensing device against direct precipitation or direct sunlight.
Definition according to ISO 6707-1: construction for closing an opening, intended primarily for access with hinged, pivoted or sliding operation.
Building elements that are external (face the outside of the building)
External door (faces the outside of the building)
External wall (faces the outside of the building)
External window (faces the outside of the building)
HVAC actuator for cooling or heating
Happening, used, or existing inside a building (by http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/indoor)
Actuator used to turn the lights on or off.
Meteorological Variables that can be measured by weather stations (this means that they are outdoors. Maybe the name has to be changed)
The direction an envelope element faces, i.e., the direction of a vector perpendicular to and pointing away from the surface outside of the element (Building Energy Codes Program).
Existing, happening, or done outside, rather than inside a building: (http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/outdoor)
Observations that stand out and do not conform to the expected behaviour
An erroneous observation (e.g. temperature, illuminance) caused by a beam spotlight. For example, an observation made by a sensing device located under a light bulb
Outliers caused by an error on the device itself
An erroneous observation caused by a malfunction suffered by the device, which might have been transient.
An erroneous observation (e.g. temperature, illuminance) caused by external factors. For example for being next to a source of radiant heat or cold such as windows and poorly insulated outside walls.
An erroneous observation (e.g. temperature) caused by its placement next to an activated HVAC system (whether it was heating or cooling)
An erroneous observation caused by rainfall.
An erroneous observation (e.g. temperature, illuminance) caused by direct sunlight.
This entity represents an address for delivery of paper based mail and other postal deliveries (IFC4Add2)
Definition according to ISO 6707-1: construction enclosing the building from above.
Skylights are light transmitting fenestration (elements filling building envelope openings) forming all, or a portion of, the roof of a building's space for daylighting purposes. (Wikipedia)
Definition according to ISO 6707-1: vertical construction usually in masonry or in concrete which bounds or subdivides a construction works and fulfils a load bearing or retaining function.

A weather station is a facility, either on land or sea, with instruments and equipment for measuring atmospheric conditions to provide information for weather forecasts and to study the weather and climate (Wikipedia)
Definition according to ISO 6707-1: Construction for closing a vertical or near vertical opening in a wall or pitched roof that will admit light and may admit fresh air.

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A method is a Description that defines or uses concepts in order to guide carrying out actions aimed at a solution with respect to a problem. It is different from a Plan, because plans could be carried out in order to follow a method, but a method can be followed by executing alternative plans.

Any Object that has a proper space region. The prototypical physical object has also an associated mass, but the nature of its mass can greatly vary based on the epistemological status of the object (scientifically measured, subjectively possible, imaginary).

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
Uniquely identified by lat/long/alt. i.e.
spaciallyIntersects(P1, P2) :- lat(P1, LAT), long(P1, LONG), alt(P1, ALT), lat(P2, LAT), long(P2, LONG), alt(P2, ALT).
sameThing(P1, P2) :- type(P1, Point), type(P2, Point), spaciallyIntersects(P1, P2).
A point, typically described using a coordinate system relative to Earth, such as WGS84.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: point

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Anything with spatial extent, i.e. size, shape, or position. e.g. people, places, bowling balls, as well as abstract areas like cubes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SpatialThing

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Measure of the Relative Humidity Indoors
Measure of the Relative Humidity Outdoors
Ratio of time on which a space is occupied by people within a given period of time.

rdf:Description.dc:description: A vocabulary for representing latitude, longitude and altitude information in the WGS84 geodetic reference datum. Version $Id: wgs84_pos.rdf,v 1.22 2009/04/20 15:00:30 timbl Exp $. See http://www.w3.org/2003/01/geo/ for more details.
rdf:Description.dc:title: WGS84 Geo Positioning: an RDF vocabulary
rdf:Description.rdfs:comment:
Recent changes to this namespace: $Log: wgs84_pos.rdf,v $ Revision 1.22 2009/04/20 15:00:30 timbl Remove the time bits which have been deal with elsewhere eg in iCal.
Revision 1.21 2009/04/20 12:52:47 timbl try again
Revision 1.20 2009/04/20 12:42:11 timbl Add Event (edited ages ago and never checked in), and location (following discussion http://chatlogs.planetrdf.com/swig/2009-04-20#T12-36-09)
Revision 1.19 2009/04/20 12:36:31 timbl Add Event (edited ages ago and never checked in), and location (following discussion http://chatlogs.planetrdf.com/swig/2009-04-20#T12-36-09)
Revision 1.18 2006/02/01 22:01:04 danbri Clarified that lat and long are decimal degrees, and that alt is decimal metres about local reference ellipsoid
Revision 1.17 2004/02/06 17:38:12 danbri Fixed a bad commit screwup
Revision 1.15 2003/04/19 11:24:08 danbri Fixed the typo even more.
Revision 1.14 2003/04/19 11:16:56 danbri fixed a typo
Revision 1.13 2003/02/19 22:27:27 connolly relaxed domain constraints on lat/long/alt from Point to SpatialThing
Revision 1.12 2003/01/12 01:41:41 danbri Trying local copy of XSLT doc.
Revision 1.11 2003/01/12 01:20:18 danbri added a link to morten's xslt rdfs viewer.
Revision 1.10 2003/01/11 18:56:49 danbri Removed datatype range from lat and long properties, since they would have required each occurance of the property to mention the datatype.
Revision 1.9 2003/01/11 11:41:31 danbri Another typo; repaired rdfs:Property to rdf:Property x4
Revision 1.8 2003/01/11 11:05:02 danbri Added an rdfs:range for each lat/long/alt property, http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#float
Revision 1.7 2003/01/10 20:25:16 danbri Longer rdfs:comment for Point, trying to be Earth-centric and neutral about coordinate system(s) at the same time. Feedback welcomed.
Revision 1.6 2003/01/10 20:18:30 danbri Added CVS log comments into the RDF/XML as an rdfs:comment property of the vocabulary. Note that this is not common practice (but seems both harmless and potentially useful).
revision 1.5 date: 2003/01/10 20:14:31; author: danbri; state: Exp; lines: +16 -5 Updated schema: Added a dc:date, added url for more info. Changed the rdfs:label of the namespace from gp to geo. Added a class Point, set as the rdfs:domain of each property. Added XML comment on the lat_long property suggesting that we might not need it (based on #rdfig commentary from implementors).
revision 1.4 date: 2003/01/10 20:01:07; author: danbri; state: Exp; lines: +6 -5 Fixed typo; several rdfs:about attributes are now rdf:about. Thanks to MortenF in #rdfig for catching this error.
revision 1.3 date: 2003/01/10 11:59:03; author: danbri; state: Exp; lines: +4 -3 fixed buglet in vocab, added more wgs links
revision 1.2 date: 2003/01/10 11:01:11; author: danbri; state: Exp; lines: +4 -4 Removed alt from the as-a-flat-string property, and switched from space separated to comma separated.
revision 1.1 date: 2003/01/10 10:53:23; author: danbri; state: Exp; basic geo vocab
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: geo

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: A comma-separated representation of a latitude, longitude coordinate.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: lat/long

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: The relation between something and the point, or other geometrical thing in space, where it is. For example, the realtionship between a radio tower and a Point with a given lat and long. Or a relationship between a park and its outline as a closed arc of points, or a road and its location as a arc (a sequence of points). Clearly in practice there will be limit to the accuracy of any such statement, but one would expect an accuracy appropriate for the size of the object and uses such as mapping .
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: location
